Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Austin Jay Brockmeier of University of Florida to conduct a research project, entitled "Signal processing techniques to separate and analyze brainwaves." during the summer of 2012 at Brain Science Institute RIKEN in Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Andrezj Cichocki.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the application of recent work on matrix and tensor constrained decomposition methods to separate sources of recurrent patterns and oscillations in local field potential and electroencephalogram data. The primary hypothesis is that these signals can be decomposed as a linear combination of sources with distinct spatio-temporal characteristics, and the revealed sources will serve as sufficient descriptors to classify behavioral or cognitive activity of interest.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brain waves are measurements of the time-varying electrical currents that occur in the brain. Since their discovery in humans in 1929 brain waves have intrigued researchers as a window into the activity of the brain. Using electrodes placed on the scalp, the electroencephalogram (EEG) provides a fairly simple way of measuring signals that are indicative of the brain's activity. In clinical cases, brain waves can also be measured directly inside the brain. We are interested in how recordings of the brain waves can be used to classify brain activity for further scientific analysis and in the long term for controlling a brain-computer interface.

 Typically, recordings involve many electrodes placed at different locations. Each recording contains contributions of neural activity from different functioning parts of the brain. By analogy, the resulting data resembles the recordings from many microphones placed around a room during a busy party. Although the data contains a tremendous amount of information, it appears in mixtures. Because of this, numerical approaches to analyze brainwaves use methods developed for separating mixtures of signals into their original components. The methods to do this involve statistics and the mathematics of linear algebra.

 

Additionally, modern recordings produce very large datasets. The electrical potential is recorded at very high sampling rates and at many locations at once. Efficiently dealing with the dimensionality is the first challenge in analyzing the data for scientific or clinical applications. The data has two inherent dimensions: space (the locations of the recordings) and the time. In cases with multiple trials, there are additional dimensions (or modes) for analysis. The multimodal nature of these signals is naturally represented in multiway arrays referred to as tensors. These multiway arrays are data storage structures generalizing matrices (like those in spreadsheets) above two dimensions. Tensor storage is handy for bookkeeping of multiway data, but the true advantage is really in terms of tensors decompositions that approximate the data. The approximations use factors organized separately along each of the different modes.

For this project, I had the opportunity to work with Dr. Cichocki, an expert on the numerical approaches for separating mixed signals. He has applied these techniques in the analysis of brain waves for state-of-art applications in brain-computer interfaces. During my stay, I had the chance to both learn from and contribute to his lab's investigations. Initially, I worked on understanding the theory and algorithms in tensor decompositions. Then I applied these algorithms to the task of identifying patterns in EEG recordings of brain waves that were associated with sensory processing. Specifically, we were trying to predict the volume of sound a subject listened to based only on their brainwaves. I implemented and tested several existing algorithms; in addition, while working with another researcher in the lab, we made novel extensions of the algorithms that were submitted for publication.
During the project, I was hosted at the RIKEN Brain Science Institute (BSI). RIKEN is one of Japan's flagship research institutes. It was an amazing experience to work with experts and research scientists from around the world at the BSI. The institute hosted a weeklong summer school seminar series during my fellowship, along with many additional seminars during the summer, where I could attend presentations from top researchers around the world on cutting-edge research.
